In this discussion, apparently we have been talking about "retrofitting" un=
it tests for old code that never before had them. The notion seems to be th=
at each method in a class, or perhaps each public method, should have a uni=
t test.

I think this is wrong. I think, as J.B. said, that in such a case =
you should concentrate on testing features, not simply methods.

I would sa=
y that for new code, where you're writing tests along with your production =
code, it might make sense to try for a test per (public) method. But that's=
 because in this case you have the benefit of thinking about the testing at=
 the time you're writing the code. I think you're more likely to design you=
r code in such a way as to have this make more sense. (The "testing influen=
ces design" notion.)

The problem I see with mindlessly (or even mindfully)=
 writing a test for each method, just to satisfy someone's idea that code c=
overage is good, is that you're likely to (1) invest a lot of (or even a li=
ttle) time; and (2) generate a lot of test code (which will have to be main=
tained, don't forget), for what will turn out to be little or no benefit. I=
 would bet that the marginal number of bugs found by "complete" per-method =
tests over a more sensible per-feature approach, both now and forever in th=
e future, is very close to zero. At least that's my impression based on my =
own experiences.

More is not always better.

I would be very curious to kn=
ow if anyone can report on actual (measured, quantitative) experiences that=
 either support or refute this.

 - Alan Bram
